This week, the Democrat News will be reviewing the last six months of headlines from 2023. In the Dec. 27 issue, we took a look at the past year from January through June. The stories below appear under the month they appeared in the Democrat News last year.
July
Madison County Clerk Don Firebaugh, Circuit Clerk Tenia Herman, Commissioner Larry Kemp and Commissioner Jason Greene cut the ribbon during the Madison County Justice Center’s Ribbon Cutting and Open House, hosted by the Madison County Chamber of Commerce. Commissioner Tom Stephens and Judge Dan Fall held each end of the ribbon during the ceremony.
****
Greg Hoskins’ Midwest-centric media company, Better Newspapers Inc., has purchased the Democrat News, Daily Journal, Farmington Press, and Advantage. These newspapers were previously owned by Lee Enterprises. Hoskins said he hopes to see these newspapers grow and embrace their roots of community-based news coverage.
****
A fun new community activity has popped up at the Fredericktown pool, bringing joy and creativity to residents of all ages. “Parks” the rock snake, an imaginative project spearheaded by April Thompson and a few local enthusiasts, has become a hit ,and everyone is invited to join in the fun.
****
The Madison County Chamber of Commerce held a ribbon cutting for the newest addition to Sawyer’s Landing, The Venue. Owners Ben and Erin Brubacher and the Brubacher family and event coordinator Kelli Hubbs decided to combine the ribbon cutting with an open house at The Venue.
****
Colonel Eric T. Olson, superintendent of the Missouri State Highway Patrol, announced Captain Philip E. Gregory, Troop E commanding officer, will retire Aug. 1, after 30 years of dedicated service. Gregory, who grew up in Fredericktown and graduated from Fredericktown High School, was appointed to the Patrol on Aug. 1, 1993, as a member of the 66th Recruit Class.
****
Soccer matches in the 2023 Optimist soccer season will be played at the sports complex due to repeated flooding at the Rotary Park.
****
The City of Fredericktown’s Board of Aldermen discussed parking downtown. City Administrator James Settle suggested working with building owners to improve areas behind downtown buildings as a way to add additional parking. Settle said, if the MCSC parking lot was able to be striped and used for parking, it would be a substantial source of much-needed parking.
August
The first FredMo Nights event at Jaycee Park drew a large crowd. In an effort to provide car collectors and the community with a relaxed gathering, local car enthusiasts Logan Mitchell and Zak Keller organized the much-anticipated FredMo Nights, which they plan to hold twice a month.
****
Grace Sharing Hope and 1 Sixteen Barber & Beauty hosted a successful free community event, as 65 people came out for free haircuts and 150 hotdog lunches were served. The Community Hearts event is something which has been put together for several years as a way to get ready for the new school year, but it is open to everyone of any age.
****
The annual Stuff the Bus event was held Saturday at the Fredericktown Walmart. It is a way for the Fredericktown and Marquand-Zion School Districts to receive donated school supplies and money to help students get the school year off on the right foot.
****
At the Madison County Chamber of Commerce monthly luncheon, members learned about what is happening as local students head back to school. Marquand-Zion Superintendent Scott Blake and Fredericktown Assistant Superintendent Melanie Allen gave updates on their districts.
****
The Madison County Chamber of Commerce held a ribbon cutting at the new Cedar Valley Bar & Grill at 1859 Madison 504. Owner Penny Davis and her husband Jim did the honors.
****
Fredericktown High School football fans got their first glimpse of the 2023 Blackcats, as new head coach Steve Williams and the Cats hosted their annual scrimmage.
****
Cap America is the tournament champion and Parsons Lawn Care finished the regular season 13-1, as the 2023 women’s league wrapped up play.
****
“A Historic Day at the Square” was an afternoon/evening of old fashioned fun, capped off with fireworks and square dancing.The event, presented by Covenant Care and The Madison County Chamber of Commerce, featured a pie baking contest, dunking booth, stick horse races, greased pig competition, pickin’ on the square, concessions, square dancing and more.
****
The Fredericktown R-I Board of Education set its tax rate and approved the budget at the Aug. 15 meeting.
****
The Fredericktown High School Marching Blackcats invited the community to a preview and Luau. This year, the band will be performing a show titled “Blackcats in Bikini Bottom” featuring music from various Spongebob Squarepants episodes and movies.
September
The heart of Fredericktown is experiencing a remarkable transformation, all due to a push from the local community and its businesses. Madison County Chamber of Commerce Executive Director Tessa Rehkop said it is really a group effort. Rehkop said the Downtown Revitalization Committee is working with the City of Fredericktown and Madison County Service Coordination to add 80 more parking spaces downtown.
****
Fredericktown High School welcomes Nickey Reutzel as its new principal for the 2023-2024 school year. Reutzel, the former Fredericktown Intermediate School principal, brings with her 17 years of experience in education, with six of those spent as an administrator. Reutzel said her decision to apply for the high school principal position was driven by her desire to work with older students again.
****
The Fredericktown High School softball team improved to 5-0 with victories over Herculaneum, 19-5; and Saxony Lutheran, 10-8.
****
As the new school year kicks off, the Fredericktown R-I School District is buzzing with excitement about its Learning Zone After School Program. This program, which kicked off Monday, not only serves the students but also extends its benefits to adults, making it a hub of learning and engagement. Learning Zone is part of the 21st Century Community Learning Center School initiative, supported by a grant which funds after-school programs.
****
Eighth District U.S. Rep. Jason Smith, chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, hosted a roundtable discussion on Monday with healthcare professionals at Madison Medical Center’s West Main Medical Building in Fredericktown. The roundtable discussions were an opportunity for health care professionals to share their ideas and proposals to improve and expand access to care in rural and underserved communities. Smith said a national Request for Information was made by the Ways and Means Committee, asking for people’s input on the many different aspects of care. He said he wanted the first listening sessions to take place in the 8th congressional district.
****
Courthouse Square played host to motorcyclists participating in the Missouri Vietnam Wall Run, a tribute to veterans and a solemn remembrance of those who never returned. Hundreds of motorcyclists from all over the state gathered in the square before heading on to Perryville where the ride ended its journey at the Vietnam Veterans Memorial Wall. During the stop in Fredericktown a small ceremony was held, beginning with a presentation of colors by cadets from the Fredericktown High School JROTC and the playing of the National Anthem. As the music filled the square, the area became silent. Caps were removed and everyone turned their attention to the giant American flag flown high by the Fredericktown Fire Department. Once the music stopped Fredericktown Mayor Travis Parker presented Ken Taylor, commander of Liberty Riders, with a proclamation in honor of POW/MIA Recognition Day.
****
Fredericktown Intermediate School started the 2023-2024 school year with a new principal, Beth Glore. Glore brings a wealth of experience to her new role, having devoted 15 years to the field of education, including her two-year tenure as Assistant Principal at Kelly A. Burlison Middle School.
****
The Madison County Chamber of Commerce’s annual banquet at Victoria Vineyards transported guests to the Wild West as they gathered in their finest western attire. The theme for this year’s event was a resounding success as table sponsors spared no effort to bring the western spirit to life.
****
The Fredericktown High School soccer team won 2-0, at North County. Miguel Milan and Marcos Navarette scored for the Cats. Carter Jordan had an assist and Brigg Hale got the shutout in goal.
****
The Madison County Chamber of Commerce held a ribbon cutting extravaganza at PK Imports, The Old Mine House, The Crazy Wildflower, and Shelter Ins. – Craig Wood.
****
The annual Pioneer Days festival in Marquand went on without a hitch last weekend. Activities and attractions included the car show, horseshoe and cornhole tournaments, balloon animal artistry, bounce houses, hair braiding, tinsel, and a variety of handmade crafts. This year’s event continued to emphasize the importance of preserving and celebrating local history. The historic Henry & Jane (Bess) Sitzes Log Homestead along with the Historical Museum were open for attendees.
October
Teachers and staff with the Fredericktown R-I School District were buzzing with excitement and new-found knowledge after a successful professional development day. The event, held on Friday, brought together educators, community members, and experts to share their insights, skills, and experiences.
****
A large crowd of adults, children, and families enjoyed the food, games, raffles, bounce houses, refreshments, baked and craft sale items and much more at the annual St. Michael Church Oktoberfest, Sunday, at the church.
****
The Fredericktown High School football team won 27-25, Friday, at De Soto.
****
With Pakey Matthew’s outgoing personality and knack for agriculture business, the high school junior fields calls from multiple states with interest in his specialty livestock business. Pakey raises and shows Angus cattle and Babydoll sheep near Fredericktown in Agri-Ready Designated Madison County. His Animal Ownership SAE “Pakey’s Farms” also includes chinchillas, tortoises and more. Pakey’s business acumen is proof of the POWER of youth entrepreneurship in Missouri agriculture.
****
Fredericktown came alive with excitement Sunday, as the community gathered for the R-I Homecoming Parade and Kick-Off party. Fredericktown R-I Assistant Superintendent Melanie Allen shared the motivation behind reviving the Homecoming Parade after a hiatus of many years.
****
The Madison County Fair was held over this past weekend. Despite some challenges, crowds of people could be seen enjoying different parts of the festivities from livestock to the truck and tractor pulls.
****
The Fredericktown High School volleyball team held its annual Pink Out Night, Oct. 3. Each year the team chooses a member of the community to celebrate them and their victories on their journey to beat cancer. This year, they selected Mark Stumbaugh, a 2000 graduate of Fredericktown High School, to honor on this special night.
****
The inaugural Bulls, Barrels, and Bands event was a bucking success as it drew crowds to the Fredericktown Lions Club Rodeo Grounds, Saturday.
****
Fredericktown High School seniors Tim Desanto and Ava Penuel were crowned Football Homecoming King and Queen during the coronation which preceded the Cats’ game against Borgia.
****
The Madison County Chamber of Commerce held a ribbon cutting ceremony, Friday, for Rusted Wren. The vintage market and boutique, located at 111 E. Main St., opened its doors that morning and had a fun-filled opening day.
****
The second Annual Furever Paws and Claws Chili Cook-Off brought the heat to downtown Fredericktown, Saturday. The chili and jalapeno eating contest covered the spice, but mother nature also felt like participating bringing temperatures around 80 degrees to the event.
****
The Fredericktown High School football team celebrated the high school careers of its seven seniors prior to Friday night’s game against East Prairie. Once the game started, the two teams exchanged long plays and combined for 13 touchdowns as Fredericktown won 57-34.
****
Downtown Fredericktown was filled with laughter, music, and good times, Friday, during the Monster Mash adult trick-or-treating event.
November
The Fredericktown Fire Department’s haunted house and hayride, with assistance from the Fredericktown High School Junior ROTC, wrapped up its spooky fundraiser last night. The community is still buzzing with excitement, or horror, as the annual “Haunting on Chamber” concluded its five-night run, despite a drop in temperatures and the cancellation of night three.
****
During regular session business, City Clerk Theresa Harbison was recognized for achieving the Missouri Registered City Clerk certification.
****
The Varsity Blackcats raced at Cape Notre Dame for the Class 3 District 1 Championships. Freshmen Laila Stephens and Breanna Bone finished with All-District honors, coming in 7th and 8th place respectively. This performance qualifies them for the Class 3 State Championships in Columbia, where they will compete for one of the top 30 spots and All-State honors.
****
The official launch party for Critical Mineral Recovery, hosted by Interco, was held Friday. The event included live music, barbeque and tours of the facility. Critical Mineral Recovery is a newly built lithium-ion battery recycling facility, located on Highway OO. The two companies say they are working together to expand the global recycling capacity of strategic metals and minerals.
****
Cap America recently made a $25,000 donation to the Mineral Area College Foundation as a part of the Mineral Area College Enhancement Grant Campaign.
****
The Brubacher family, friends, and guests gather for a Madison County Chamber of Commerce ribbon cutting, Saturday, at The Treehouse at Sawyer’s Landing. Some of the younger family members did the honors, cutting the ribbon.
****
The Community Beautification Committee presented SMTS with the first ornament of the season. The yearly ornament fundraiser choses a business, landmark or significant event to feature. This year SMTS celebrates serving Southeast Missouri for 50 years and the committee could not think of a more fitting feature for this year’s theme.
****
Each year, the Fredericktown High School JROTC and the R-I District host a Veterans breakfast, followed by a parade of veterans through the parking lots of each of the R-I campuses.
****
The Glass Slipper “Walk In Confidence” Fashion Show was Nov. 10, at The Venue in Madison County. The Glass Slipper carries new and used dresses and accessories and menswear for all occasions and in all sizes.
****
Surrounded by friends, family, co-workers, and chamber members, owner Shonda Matthews did the honors as the Madison County Chamber of Commerce hosted a ribbon cutting at Georgie Kay’s Boutique, at 925 Highway OO, in Madison County.
****
The Fredericktown High School girls basketball team opened the 2023-24 season with a 69-49 victory over the Woodland Cardinals, here.
****
“Welcome to the Pajama Party Concert. We are already in our pajamas, but don’t worry. We’ll have you home by bedtime!” With these words by Fredericktown Intermediate music teacher, Tracy King, the annual 4th grade concert began.
****
Following a presentation made by two high school students at the Nov. 21 meeting of the Fredericktown R-1 Board of Education, it was decided this year’s prom will be held off-campus as a private, non-school-affiliated event.
****
A festive spirit filled the air as Madison County celebrated Small Business Saturday, a day dedicated to supporting the local businesses that make the community thrive. Downtown Fredericktown transformed into a bustling marketplace, with pop-up shops lining the streets and enticing shoppers with their unique offerings.
December
Individuals both young and old were seen smiling throughout the afternoon and evening, Saturday, as downtown Fredericktown and the surrounding area hosted the eighth annual Miracles on Main Street celebration.
****
FHS basketball homecoming candidates/escorts are: Representing FBLA and DECA Jackson Smith, Representing BETA Braden Braswell, Escort Pakey Matthews, Representing Band Rubin Pirtle, Representing Basketball Zander Stephens, Representing FCCLA Noah Cole, Representing JROTC Dawson Cook, Representing Scholar Bowl Nathanael White, Representing FFA Gavin Graham, Escort Kaylee Wagganer, Representing BETA Terri Duffel, Representing Publications Mattie Miller, Representing Choir Nadia Mills, Representing Basketball Keira Francis, Representing FCCLA Nikolija Mihajlovic, Representing JROTC Tone
Magill, Representing Student Council Ashley Avalos, and Representing FFA Leah Thompson.
****
Members of the Madison County Retired School Personnel (MCRSP) lived out the state organization motto “To serve and not be served,” when they volunteered to help our local Salvation Army Chapter by participating in the Salvation Army Bell Ringing Campaign.
****
Eighth-grade students from Kelly A. Burlison Middle school participated in an immersive and interactive Game of Life activity event hosted by the Madison County Chamber of Commerce. The event aimed to provide students with a hands-on experience of the real world financial decisions they will face as adults.
****
Recently, Olympic Steakhouse has been transformed into the Mad Cow Steakhouse. Owners and Fredericktown residents Andy and Laura Michael have reopened the doors of the town’s long standing restaurant, bringing back tradition, great food and friendly service.
****
The Fredericktown High School boys basketball team came from behind to defeat the Perryville Pirates, 46-29, at Friday’s homecoming matchup, at FHS. Braden Braswell and Keira Francis were crowned the 2023 Fredericktown High School basketball homecoming king and queen, prior to Friday’s varsity game.
****
The Fredericktown FFA chapter held its annual Barnwarmin’. All week, students worked hard, clearing out the shop and turning it into a dance floor. The BBQ Team barbecued hot dogs, and had chili for chili dogs. 2023 Barnwarming King and Queen are Addie Shetley and Caleb Feltz.
****
The 2023 Shop With a Hero event afforded 123 local children the opportunity to shop with their “hero,” at the Fredericktown Walmart.
****
The Fredericktown High School girls basketball team improved to 5-5 on the season with a 60-48 victory over Arcadia Valley, here.
****
November 28, Clara Basden participated in the Missouri Association of Soil & Water Conservation Districts State Public Speaking event. She was one of six state finalists and the Southeast District Representative.
